nodes.bodyText:
Here is some logic that PackageManger knows about the internal file structure of PackageStore.
Would it make sense if the store handles downloading as well?
Otherwise, if you want the package manager to be 100% unaware of how the store keeps its packages, you will need to define an interface between the manager and the store which I think is an overkill.

No, it doesn't know about the internal folder structure. It just uses it after getting it from  PackageStore.
About the interface, personally I prefer having an interface for PackageStore because it forces us to think about the boundary. But I didn't do it mainly because our DI doesn't support binding implementation to interface yet and also it is an overkill.
Is making this package private (as opposed to private) intentional?

nodes.bodyText: What do we need NoArgsConstructor for?
Our DI needs a @Inject constructor or a no-arg constructor. This class use the latter~
I'm little confused. We have listAvailablePackageMetadata in both packageStore and packageManager?

Exactly and I hope this is a good example for encapsulation and independence.
Both listAvailablePackageMetadata returns the same thing - available versions that satisfy the version constraint.
But PackageStore::listAvailablePackageMetadata does this on local disk,
where PackageManager::listAvailablePackageMetadata does this with its own logic -  looking for action version, listing from local, listing from cloud.
In summary, they are doing listAvailablePackageMetadata at their own scope. The logic is encapsulated and independent.
